Award.AwardTitle: 2019 Theory Winter School on Strongly Correlated and Quantum Spin Liquid Physics, Weyl and Topological Physics, and New Computational Techniques.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will partially support the participation of approximately 20 participants in the 2019 Theory Winter School at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory in Tallahassee Florida, which will take place from January 7th to January 11th. Preference will be given to supporting graduate students, postdoc, and junior faculty participants. The winter school will feature lectures from leading scientists, and will address current challenges in theoretical and experimental condensed matter physics, discussing new ideas and future research directions, and will enable networking and future collaborations among the participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The MagLab Theory Winter School was conducted from January 7 – 11, 2019. The title of the school was “Synergies between Real Materials, Model Hamiltonians, and Beyond", broadly consistent with the mission statement of the MagLab. The organizers were Hitesh J. Changlani (FSU and NHMFL), Turan Birol (U Minnesota), Kemp Plumb (Brown), Vladimir Dobrosavljevic (FSU and NHMFL) and Laura Greene (FSU and NHMFL). 10 speakers delivered lectures on a wide range of topics:

 

Jennifer Cano - Topological insulators and semimetals

 

Efstratios Manousakis – Weyl physics transition metal dichalcogenides

Luis Balicas – Transport in topological semimetals

B. Andrei Bernevig – Topological quantum chemistry

Nandini Trivedi - Topological and superconducting systems

Collin Broholm - Quantum spin liquids

Rebecca Flint – Frustrated magnetism

Steve White - DMRG and new methods for electronic structure

Kristjan Haule - DFT + Dynamical Mean Field Theory

As can be seen from the topics, the school addressed current challenges in modern condensed matter physics. Multifaceted approaches that bring together the study of model Hamiltonians, ab-initio methods and experiments to gain new understanding of quantum materials were highlighted. This synergy will impact endeavors where theory is guiding new discoveries.  Videos of the school lectures and tutorial can be accessed on:

 

https://nationalmaglab.org/news-events/events/2019-theory-winter-school

 

The lectures and tutorials were attended by roughly 70 students from a diverse set of backgrounds – including theorists, computational physicists and experimentalists. This diversity created an invigorating atmosphere; which led to many lively discussions. The feedback we received was overwhelmingly positive and by all metrics the school was a great success. Efforts were made to ensure that women, the underrepresented group in STEM, were fairly represented both in terms of speakers (3 out of 10) and accepted students.

 

The lectures were supplemented with three hands-on tutorial sessions on (1) topological insulators and semimetals (J.Cano and E.Manousakis) (2) quantum spin liquids from mean field ansatz and variational Monte Carlo (R. Flint and H.Changlani) and (3) DFT+DMFT for real materials (T. Birol and K. Haule). Content of these tutorials was made accessible on USBs and on the web at: https://sites.google.com/site/hiteshchanglani/teaching

 

Two student poster sessions were organized and three poster awards were handed out for each session.

 

In addition, the students were given a tour of the state-of-the-art facilities of the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory.
